item.title: Using GitHub Actions to deploy a .Net Web App - Azure Greg
item.description: So I wanted to take a look into GitHub Action’s and deploy a .Net Web App, this is my first real look into them and will be blogging about them a lot more in the future, below are the steps I took to do this. Create a basic .Net MVC Web App using .Net Core...Read More
item.author: (by Gregor Suttie)

item.title: Amazon Relief Fund
item.description: The Amazon Relief Fund was created to help individuals who are facing financial hardship immediately after a natural disaster or an unforeseen personal hardship. The Fund relies primarily on individual donations from individuals and support from Amazon.com Services LLC to fund this program. Every contribution helps and when combined with the donations of others can provide a tax-free grant (USA) to help a fellow individual in need when they are facing the unexpected.

item.title: Siouxsie Wiles & Toby Morris: what does 'level two' mean – and why does it matter?
item.description:
The alert system signals the start of a new phase in NZ's battle against Covid-19. Siouxsie Wiles explains what it means, with illustrations by Toby Morris.

item.title: Audible Stories | Audible.com
item.description: Free stories for kids of all ages. Audible Stories is a free website where kids of all ages can listen to hundreds of Audible audio titles across six different languages—English, Spanish, French, German, Italian and Japanese—for free, so they can keep learning, dreaming and just being kids.

item.title: Build This 8-Bit Home Computer With Just 5 Chips - IEEE Spectrum
item.description: There’s something persistently appealing about 8-bit computing: You can put together a self-contained system that’s powerful enough to be user friendly but simple enough to build and program all by yourself. Most 8-bit machines built by hobbyists today are powered by a classic CPU from the heroic age of home computers in the 1980s, when millions of spare TVs were commandeered as displays. I’d built one myself, based on the Motorola 6809. I had tried to use as few chips as possible, yet I still needed 13 supporting ICs to handle things such as RAM or serial communications. I began to wonder: What if I ditched the classic CPU for something more modern yet still 8-bit? How low could I get the chip count?
item.author: (By Matt Sarnoff)

item.title: Lattices: New Cryptographic Capabilities | Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing
item.description: Lattices have helped us achieve cryptographic goals that were a cryptographer’s dream for decades. This includes fully homomorphic encryption, homomorphic signatures, attribute-based encryption schemes and many more. Part of the interest in lattice-based cryptography stems from the fact that currently, it is the only way to construct these advanced cryptographic schemes. This
